ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about photography basics including how to use a DSLR camera, using camera RAW, Adobe Photoshop & Bridge basics, and learning how to put together a photobook.

I learned how to use a camera, how to use Adobe Bridge and Camera Raw, some history of photography, and how to think and talk about pictures. Near the end, I began to develop my own photographic voice.

Developed our skills as photographers, from composing images to working with photoshop. We also learned how to participate in critiques, think about art more critically, and composing a photography book as our final project.
So much! The basic techniques of how to use a digital camera, using Adobe bridge and photoshop, how to create a photobook, and also history of photography and its different genres.
How to use photoshop, bridge, camera raw, blurb book editor, and a few works by some famous contemporary photographers.
I learned how to tackle digital color photography, and some essential Photoshop and Bridge skills. I also shot in camera raw for the first time, which has been such a wonderful experience.
Learned how to think about the composition of a good photo, and also how to better use the camera

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think having more guest lectures where we get to learn more from other artists about their own photographic practice would provide a great learning opportunity. Learning and teaching photography over zoom is no easy task, and despite these challenges, this course was great! The lectures were engaging, the critiques were really helpful, and I learned so much while enjoying the process.

AMAZING CLASS. TAKE IT. Having this over zoom was obviously not ideal, but I really loved this class. Ted is AMAZING. He is the most chill professor ever. Majority of my class was first time photographers and Ted never made us feel dumb. Taking photos in new haven was such a great way to explore parts of the city I had never seen and to meet so many new people. I learnt so much and really fell in love with photography.
I wish we could've gone on group photography expeditions, but unfortunately due to COVID-19 restrictions we couldn't. Hopefully in the future this course can engage in more of these sessions!

It was really good about giving us an idea about what makes a photo interesting. The photoshop tutorials were also good, however obviously harder to understand over virtual lecture. The part that could have been better was more instruction about using the actual camera.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: watching the photoshop tutorials on our own were helpful towards reducing zoom fatigue, and having some class time dedicated to working on our photos was also really helpful.
It was a little bit difficult to follow Photoshop lessons over Zoom, but once sessions can meet in person in a computer lab, these issues will be cleared up.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes
definitely try to take this or another photo class before you graduate!! it's so much fun and Ted is an awesome teacher.

Yes! If you have even the slightest bit of interest in photography, you must take this class with Ted. Most people in my seminar had no prior experience with photography so it was a great learning environment and we all helped each other out. Critiques were also well-facilitated, and I learned to hone my skills on a particular photo subject by the end of the course.
Yes! This is a great introduction to digital photography.

Yes!! (especially if they're interested in photography). It was a fun class, we learned a lot, and it was great being able to see and discuss all our classmates' work. (and I imagine it's even better in person!:))

YES. hundred percent. This class is amazing, irrespective of whether youve done photography before or not. Its entirely what you make of it, you can put in as much work as you want to get out of it. Photography is such a great medium to explore new places and meet people and this class will teach you everything from the technical aspects to just how to think about your photography and want you want to say through your photos. Ted is the best professor, he is so chill and just always so willing to help in whatever way you need.

I absolutely would. I grew so much as an artist, photographer, and contemplator of photography. This is such an inspiring course, and has given me lifelong skills with my camera. What a wonderful course.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
Going out and taking photos individually, by ourselves.
Virtual seminar
